Introduction

Defense mechanisms are unconscious means of responding and adapting to situations to minimize anxiety and promote self-preservation.  Defense mechanisms are crucial to both normal and pathologic behavior and help manage stress, anxiety, and unacceptable impulses.

Classification of defense mechanisms



Defense mechanisms can be broadly classified into 2 categories: mature and immature.  These classifications aid in understanding the adaptive value of defense mechanisms and the potential for pathologic behavior.

Mature defense mechanisms



These mechanisms are considered adaptive and promote healthy functioning.  They include:



  • Altruism:  deriving pleasure from helping others, often at a personal cost

    • Example:  volunteering at a free clinic to cope with one's feelings of inadequacy
  • Sublimation:  channeling unacceptable impulses into socially acceptable behaviors
    • Example:  taking up sports or exercise (eg, boxing) to deal with aggressive impulses
  • Suppression:  consciously putting unwanted feelings aside to cope with reality
    • Example:  a student choosing to focus on exams, putting aside worries about a family issue until later
  • Humor:  using humor to deflect anxiety or uncomfortable feelings
    • Example:  making a joke in a tense situation to lighten the mood

Immature defense mechanisms



These are considered maladaptive and are often seen in children and adults with certain psychiatric disorders (particularly personality disorders).



  • Projection:  attributing one's own unacceptable thoughts or feelings to another

    • Example:  accusing another person of being angry or hostile when oneself is actually feeling that way
  • Denial:  behaving as if an aspect of reality does not exist
    • Example:  a patient refusing to accept a cancer diagnosis despite a biopsy-proven diagnosis
  • Regression:  reverting to behaviors typical of an earlier developmental stage
    • Example:  an adult throwing a temper tantrum when faced with stress
  • Splitting:  viewing people and/or situations as "all good" or "all bad," with no middle ground (common in borderline personality disorder) 
    • Example:  idealizing a mentor one moment and then completely devaluing them the next when they provide constructive criticism
  • Passive aggression:  indirectly expressing aggression toward others by expressing hostility covertly, often through procrastination, stubbornness, or intentional inefficiency
    • Example:  a student who is upset with a peer agreeing to help them with a project but "forgetting" to do their part
  • Acting out:  directly expressing unconscious emotions through actions rather than reflecting on the emotions
    • Example:  engaging in risky behavior (eg, excessive drinking) to express underlying feelings of distress
  • Transference:  the process of recreating patterns from important developmental relationships (eg, parents, siblings, teachers) with another person, an unconscious process that includes reactivating related emotions, thoughts, and behaviors
    • Example:  a patient developing strong feelings, positive or negative, toward their therapist that are actually rooted in feelings about a parent

Neurotic defense mechanisms



These mechanisms are a subset of immature defense mechanisms that are common in adults and provide short-term relief but can lead to long-term issues.



  • Repression:  unconsciously blocking unacceptable thoughts and feelings from conscious awareness

    • Example:  forgetting a traumatic childhood event
  • Displacement:  redirecting emotions from a "dangerous" object to a "safe" object
    • Example:  a person who is angry at their boss taking out their frustration on a family member
  • Rationalization:  justifying behaviors or feelings (with seemingly logical reasons) to avoid the true explanation
    • Example:  a student who failed an exam rationalizing the result by claiming there was not enough time to study rather than acknowledging a lack of understanding
  • Reaction formation:  transforming an unacceptable impulse into its opposite
    • Example:  treating someone you dislike in an overly friendly manner to hide your true feelings
  • Intellectualization:  using excessive reasoning or logic to deal with emotional stress, thereby avoiding the emotional aspect
    • Example:  focusing on the technical details of a serious diagnosis rather than dealing with the emotional impact
  • Isolation of affect:  separating thoughts from feelings, thereby removing the emotional impact
    • Example:  describing a traumatic event without showing any emotion
  • Undoing:  attempting to reverse or undo a thought or feeling by performing an action that signifies an opposite feeling
    • Example:  being overly nice to someone after having an aggressive thought about them

Application in clinical practice



For health care providers, recognizing one's own defense mechanisms is crucial for a therapeutic physician-patient relationship.  Such recognition allows the provider to cultivate the self-awareness needed to manage stress and improve emotional intelligence.  Similarly, recognzing defense mechanisms in patients is necessary to help facilitate effective communication that ultimately benefits the patient's understanding of their diagnosis, treatment, and prognosis.
